dialogues.text: With as much dignity as he can muster, rings the bell. Swann opens the door. His eyes dart quickly about, as if checking for exits, possible weapons-- But that's the wor moment, and when that moment ends, quick as it begun, the just stare. Taking each other's measure. Then:

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Inspector Juve? Juve nods.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What may I offer you? Juve shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (finally) Have you come to arrest me? Juve just laughs, bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (softly) What, then? From his inside breast pocket, Juve extracts the envelope it to Swann for his inspection.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm having a whiskey. May I fix you one? Juve says nothing, but accepts the offered drink.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are, Monsieur, a welcome guest in my house. But on my fullest honor, I have never seen this invitation before. Swann raises a glass. The gesture is not reciprocated.

dialogues.speaker: JUVE
dialogues.text: (regaining his speech) F-Father in heaven. Swann sits slightly behind Juve, in the manner of a psychoanalyst.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: JUVE
dialogues.text: F-- F-- For thirty years.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: You have seen me eight times since then. But you did not know it. Juve drains his drink, gathering the courage to say the w almost cannot speak.

dialogues.speaker: JUVE
dialogues.text: F-Fantomas.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Charles Swann. My friends call me Charley.  Swann pours him a refill, which Juve downs in one gulp.

dialogues.speaker: JUVE
dialogues.text: This is not right.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: You may recall my late wife, Céline. But you have not met my daughter. She's outside now, and should be done with her work in an hour or so. (beat ) I would be honored if you would stay for dinner. Should you join us, I would ask one courtesy, only one. My daughter. She knows nothing of my past.

dialogues.speaker: JUVE
dialogues.text: (flatly) You ruined my life.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: You did your best to ruin mine, as I recall.

dialogues.speaker: JUVE
dialogues.text: (brightening) I can only hope so.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Be that as it may. The invitation you received, my dear Monsieur Juve, was not of my hand. Someone wanted you to come here. Someone--is there any other reason?-- Wanted one of us dead. Juve takes this in. SWANN (cont'd) One of us, perhaps-- Swann offers Juve a cigar, which Juve declines. With prec elegant motions, Swann picks up a sterling knife, and, wi small flourish, nips the very tip of the Montecristo. SWANN (cont'd) --or both of us. Swann lights up. Looks reflectively out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, in the garden: NORA, an apparition in white. Cover head-to-toe. Bent low, as if gardening, or studying somet close to the earth. A floppy suit, a loose white helmet: one might wear, out for a stroll, on the moons of Saturn.  10.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some 20 miles outside of Palm Springs, a forest of high-t wind-driven generators, each on its own steel tower. Ther perhaps two hundred of them. The wind is quite gentle now the blades, as they turn lazily, emit a smooth, soothing whup sound. The white Rolls Silver Shadow pulls off the highway, driv across an unpaved road to one of the nearer towers. The D gets out of the car, gun in hand, followed by two CAPTIVE Asian businessmen in suits and ties; one young, one somew elderly. The captives have been blindfolded, their hands bound with black silken cord. Next comes LEMUEL HARDT, a tough guy with a Harvard MBA. finally, the boss: VICTOR HOLLYWOOD, a vigorous man in hi sixties, tanned, fit, pampered, sporting a trim white bea is wearing white shorts, a Lacoste shirt, and a Rolex as the Ritz. The Driver places the captives up against the cross-brace tower. The younger man, GONDO KEN, is visibly nervous; th older, GONDO HIDEKI, a model of detachment. Lem addresses the elder man.

dialogues.speaker: LEM
dialogues.text: (Japanese; subtitled) Gondo-san. Mr. Hollywood wishes to give his permission for you to remove your blindfold.

dialogues.speaker: HIDEKI
dialogues.text: (in English) Only if we both may do so. Lem looks at Hollywood, who nods.

dialogues.speaker: LEM
dialogues.text: (in English) Your pleasure is our desire. The captives undo the blindfolds. Hollywood paces back an forth in front of them. Abruptly, he reaches into his poc and extracts a gleaming compact disc. And begins to speak casual American accent betraying, in the Ws and Ts, just of the Continent.  11.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: Do you know why a compact disc has sixty-five minutes of play time? Because Mr. Akio Morita, of Sony, decided it must have the capacity to hold Bach's cello suites, without interruption. He hands the disc to Lem, who inserts it in the Rolls' pl The cello suite, number 6, D minor, Pierre Fournier's ren haunting, poignant, elegiac.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (over the music) The technology of the compact disc was not held in the tight fist of one Zaibatsu. It was licensed. There is greater profit, by many orders of magnitude. And glorious music encircles the world. Hollywood's hands move in time with the music, as if he w conducting. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) No one owns the wind. We see, close the tall, eerily majestic machines HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) But these generators make electricity, bringing power -- (beat ) --at a profit-- (beat ) --to Palm Springs, to Rancho Mirage... Jewels in the desert. A gesture from Hollywood, and the Driver, pointing with h binds Ken to the tower with silvered gaffer's tape. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) Now you, Gondo-san, are in possession of an extraordinary technology. The Novium chip is, if I may be so bold, a device for which the inventors are fully deserving of the Nobel. And if our business had a Nobel, Ken and yourself are fully deserving of it, for spiriting the chip from its inventors, and offering it to us.

dialogues.speaker: HIDEKI
dialogues.text: Offering it for sale. Ken's wrist and ankles are fastened, one by one, each wit own gleaming chrome handcuff. The Driver then slathers Ke  12. body with a gelatinous glop. [It's electroconductive, the they use for EKGs in hospitals. ]

dialogues.text: I do not want to own it; I want to borrow it. Reproduce it. (beat ) I would like your chip to find a place in every personal computer, every web browser -- In every household in the developed world. The Driver takes a sharp-bladed shovel from the trunk of Rolls and begins to dig a ditch a few feet from the tower

dialogues.speaker: HIDEKI
dialogues.text: If we might talk price.

The Driver does not have to dig long. He hits a length of cable, cuts it in two, fastens the "live" end to the towe metal superstructure with more tape, more "glop." HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) ...is where you've hidden the chip. Hideki, watching the Driver, listening to Hollywood, keep face impassive. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) In this season, the valley cools dramatically just after sunset. The drop in temperature creates a low pressure zone; and the winds start to blow. At thirty-five miles per hour through the pass. Enough for each of these puppies-- To generate some eighteen thousand volts of electricity. (beat ) Impressive-- Yes? dialogues.speaker: HIDEKI
dialogues.text: You need not wait for an answer (beat ) It is immaterial to me, whether you make the world's largest fortune, or whether you drop it down a sewerpipe. I don't want to be your partner. I want-- All I want-- Is for you to meet my price. (beat ) And since you are unwilling to do this, I have only one answer. Which is... (beat ) ...that you may fuck yourself.

dialogues.text: You're a man of honor, Gondo-san. I will not insult you by asking you to change your mind. Hollywood reaches into his jacket and comes out holding a calibre Beretta. It is what's known, in professional circ as a "ladies' gun"; and it's what James Bond used, before traded up to a Walther. Hollywood looks at Hideki imploringly. Hideki is complete motionless, almost tranquil. Ken, twitching uncontrollably, watches as Hollywood takes his father.

dialogues.text: his hair standing on end, sparks flying from his wrists performing some extraordinary acts of contortion, until h just about--but not quite--reach the power line. Hair on end, wrists charred, extracts a yellow map pin fr notch of his lapel--the insignia, if it matters, of membe in Mensa--and goes to work picking the locks. In the very last light, the locks spring, and a weakened crawls across the desert floor to the body of his slain f He manages to extract from his father's breast pocket the business card which Hollywood had placed there. Racked by sobs, shock, exhaustion, Ken clutches the card collapses across the lifeless body of his father.

dialogues.text: The buyer! His name! Juve runs out of breath and falls, face down, into the mu cobblestone ground. The streetsweeper, its engines echoin loudly in the walled-off space, bears down on him, slowly implacably.

dialogues.speaker: THE STREETSWEEPER
dialogues.text: The oversized wheels. The blade-like wire brushes--one ro clockwise, the other counterclock--gobbling everything in path. Which, right now, means Inspector Juve, retired. Starting with his shoes. Juve flashes Swann a desperate "V" with his outstretched arm-- The last of him to go. Ken stops the machine. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: THE ALLEYWAY
dialogues.text: No Swann. Ken moves, with cat-like grace, down the alleyway, inspec the trash-bins, the sealed-up windows, tapping the mortar back-wall bricks. Buildings on two sides. A brick wall at the rear. And the Massive streetsweeper, sealing off the entrance. There is way that Swann could have escaped. The streetsweeper backs out. Ken's deadpan nearly screens trace of his frustration. We FOLLOW the streetsweeper as heads west on First Street, away from the dawn.  39.

dialogues.speaker: THE ALLEYWAY
dialogues.text: No noise, no movement, no trace of life. A few trash bins discarded automobile fender, a drainpipe which casts a sl shadow. The shadow is perhaps three inches at its widest, enough to hide an alleycat, let alone a man. It is from this shadow that Swann emerges, treading softl toward daylight.

dialogues.speaker: FEATURING THE CLUB
dialogues.text: open, just a crack. Where

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: hidden, trembling, peers out, watching this man, Charley materialize... ...from thin air. And walk away. Eddie ventures into the alleyway. And only now sees

dialogues.speaker: THE BODY
dialogues.text: of Juve. In name, in blood, in other ways Eddie has spent life trying not to acknowledge-- His father Eddie bends down, low. Presses his head into Juve's chest Listening for a heartbeat. Listening for something... ...that's not there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: heads home. Swann passes the Western Exterminating buildi neon rats blinking their way clockwise around the facade. FOLLOW as Swann heads north, toward the hills. This time, there is no music on the radio, no singalong, silence, as Swann realizes that like it or not, his early retirement has come to an abrupt end. That he can no long continue, as he has for the past 25 years, the life he's living. Or perhaps, he realizes now-- The life he's been pretendi live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Swann pulls into the driveway, lining his car up besid Nora's Volvo.  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is half a child's, half an adult's. On the shelv stuffed toys vie for space with hundreds of books, most o on entomology. Swann bends down, gently kisses her cheek. Nora smiles a in her sleep. Fussily, Swann adjusts the covers on her be Then goes to the shelf, retrieving an ancient stuffed bea which he places in the bed with his daughter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bookcase, Swann pulls out a volume--the hardcover William Irish's The Night Has a Thousand Eyes--and reache the empty space with his right hand. The entire bookcase to rotate, 90 degrees, opening into a small room beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: turns on a dim overhead bulb, which casts melodramatic sh on the bare walls. There's a chair, a simple table, and a up steamer trunk. That's it. Swann sits down, his head bowed, hands clasped as if in p And, after a few extraordinarily silent moments, speaks i low, private tone.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Céline. And then, doubts resolved, he moves swiftly toward the st trunk, blowing years of accumulated dust from the old-fas padlock.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE LOCK
dialogues.text: as Swann inserts the key. Swann's face is very solemn, very still. But his eyes bet emotion: now fear, now the excitement of a small child on Christmas morning.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRUNK
dialogues.text: The lid swings open. One by one, Swann pulls the slide on trunk's interior drawers. The top one contains an amazing array of jewels: diamonds emeralds, rubies, most of them in art deco settings.  41. The second one contains newspaper clippings, yellowed now in English, some in French, all bearing headlines which c the word FANTOMAS. The third contains a variety of well-machined brass tools of which appear to be lock picks, some of which seem to b grapples and pitons for climbing. Some rope, some pulleys optical devices with lenses and mirrors, the purpose of w can only guess at. The fourth--somewhat larger--contains a dress suit: boile shirtfront, cutaway tails, black trousers, silken top hat a slim, black, elegant mask, of silk moiré, covering the the face, two perfectly placed slits for the wearer's eye Awash with poignance, Swann fingers the mask he's not wor nearly a quarter-century. Re-folds it with care. And extr in one neat motion

dialogues.speaker: THE RING
dialogues.text: from the tailcoat's breast pocket. It's a large signet ri the type one uses for stamping one's marque in sealing wa It's platinum surface gone slightly dull now, the ring fe an ornate, rococo

dialogues.speaker: F,
dialogues.text: engraved, right-to-left, dead-center.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN'S LEFT HAND
dialogues.text: as he removes his plain gold wedding band and replaces it the ring of Fant6émas.

dialogues.speaker: INT. EDDIE'S PLACE
dialogues.text: The converted garage which serves Eddie's home. The place filled to the brim with two of everything. There's a coup electric guitars (one Fender, one Gibson Les Paul); an IB and a Macintosh; two surfboards, one long, one short. The stretched canvas of large proportions on the easel. Every is piled on top of everything else and Eddie is on a matt the floor, pillow pulled over his head. The television bl Once again, Eddie is sleeping with the TV on.

dialogues.text: the anchorwoman is narrating a story.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN
dialogues.text: The slain clubowner, according to police, was retired French police detective Theophile Juve. An obscure figure, Juve was known in (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANCHORWOMAN(cont 'd) Europe, sources report, for his unsuccessful pursuit -- Someone is pounding at the door. ANCHORWOMAN (cont'd) --of such legendary arch-criminals as Fant6mas, Mabuse, the insidious Fu Manchu. The three, who sometimes worked together ina gang called The Spiders, were the scourge of several continents in the years after World War II. He pads to the refrigerator, across the hundreds of sheet crumpled newspaper which cover the floor

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Cool it, I'm coming, I'm coming.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN
dialogues.text: Mabuse, raised as a child within the Nazi ministry of propaganda, killed himself in an insane asylum in Germany in 1957. Doctor Fu Manchu, who would now be one hundred twenty years old, is believed dead. Fantomas, still officially at large, has not been heard from since the seventies. Eddie pulls the handle on the corrugated metal garage doo Standing there is Swann, backlit by daylight.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Surf's up.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It's Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: All day. Swann takes a step to the side, allowing the sunlight to Eddie full in the face.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We need to talk, young man. Eddie covers his eyes. Swann pushes him backwards, the newspaper-lined floor crackling loudly with each step. Sw puts one foot behind Eddie's ankle and, with the tip of o finger, sends Eddie sprawling.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN
dialogues.text: Last night's killing at the Café Karaoke may have closed the book on a colorful chapter in the history of crime.  43. Swann grabs the dropcloth which cover's Eddie's desk. Wit conjurer's deft flick of the wrist, Swann YANKS the dropc free. There is a great clatter-- But each and every one o objects on Eddie's desk lands in place.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I could just as easily snap your neck. Eddie, surveying the room, is forced to agree.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened last night?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You were there. Swann takes a can of beer, pours it into the airvents on the Macintosh. Fumes arise from within as the thing short

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Don't make me repeat myself.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I don't know anything more than you know.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Nice stick. He picks up one of the surfboards, hurls it through the n finished painting.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: This kind of shit's supposed to make me trust you? (beat ) Juve was doing fine-- Until you sent him that note.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I was doing quite well myself. Until your Mr Juve showed up on my doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: All he wanted was a decent burial.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: And where was he going to get the money for his decent burial?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: He'd made an introduction.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I know that.  44.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Between a Japanese guy with a hot piece of silicon.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: And some rich guy was going to buy it.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: That's all I know.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: You think I am fucking around? All restraint lost, Swann storms and hurls, turning the r into a complete shambles. His rage is terrifying. When ne everything in the room is broken, he picks up the Fender, preparing to smash it, Pete Townsend-style. Something mak stop. He puts the guitar down, and backs Eddie up against wall. The two, inches apart, breathe into each others' faces.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am sorry. But I could have been killed last night. I need some answers. And now some-- Slacker-- Can't remember what he ate for breakfast. Swann picks up the Fender telecaster once more, examining carefully. It's a classic.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What year?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Sixty-two.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Nice. Swann places the guitar gently against the wall. Eddie looks at Swann: a man who threatens to break necks, who stops at damaging an old guitar. He's impressed. Finally: Eddie reaches into his pocket, comes up with a p paper. It's a call slip from the karaoke bar.  45.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: The first time he came 'round the club to talk to Juve, he filled this out. Gondo Ken. The song he requested was J-9.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: "Heartbreak Hotel." Eddie points to the newspapers on the floor. Smiles. Atte a bravado he can't quite carry off:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Burglar alarm. Anyone tries to sneak up on me in my sleep, I hear ‘em: crunch crunch crunch. Swann just... ...looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora, ironing a shirt. Swann, emerging from the bathroom, wrapped in a thick Tur robe.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: You didn't have to do that

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Someone has to look after you.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Are you forgetting? She looks at him: SWANN (cont'd) If you know how to iron a shirt-- (beat ) It's because I taught you. He studies her work. SWANN (cont'd) Placket first.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Where have you been?  46.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Then the cuffs. The sleeves, inside out. The collar --

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: How did you get yourself so dirty? What have you- - (beat ) Done to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: --the front with the buttonholes, the back the front with the buttons.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: You did a good job, on the collar. Now, only now: he smiles. SWANN (cont'd) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: glides up Alameda to the Chinatown gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swann--elegant once more--enters an elaborately carved do up in Han Dynasty style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiting room of a man known simply as "The Doctor," a specialist in herbal remedies and, from time to time, oth violent cures. There are perhaps 15 Chinese--old and youn and women, mostly quite poor--waiting their turn.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Do you have an appointment?

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Tell him a man calling himself Mister Charles Swann is here to see him. Tell him that man said, "it is urgent." Swann sits down, leafs through an ancient copy of Argosy.  47.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Mr. Swann? Swann stands up, enduring the stares of 15 pairs of eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three walls are lined with jars and boxes of herbs and medicaments, labeled in a variety of foreign languages. T fourth wall looks out onto the Chinatown mall. There is a leather examination table, and a desk. In contrast to the general clutter, the massive teak desk absolutely bare, with the sole exception of a clear glass APOTHECARY JAR, in which what seems to be a PICKLE floats formaldehyde. Behind the desk is a Chinese MAN with wrinkled skin and a white beard. It would scarcely be possible to imagine any older.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I am looking for a Japanese gentleman by the name of Gondo Ken.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Patience. The Doctor leans back in his chair. THE DOCTOR (cont'd) In my office we observe certain formalities. Beginning with, "Hello."

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Forgive me. Hello, Doctor. It gives me great pleasure to see you once more, and I am grateful that you could fit me in on such short notice.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: The pleasure, Mr. Swann, is mine. The Doctor reaches under his desk and pulls out two water tumblers, and a brown glass bottle of something very old. pours. THE DOCTOR (cont'd) So. You are looking for the man who killed Inspector Juve.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Word gets around.  48.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I suppose you want to thank him for the favor? Swann permits himself a smile. THE DOCTOR (cont'd) The man disposes of a particularly irksome inspector. Yet you act as if the inspector were your friend; and his assailant your enemy. Why, Mr. Swann? The world has so many inspectors. He lifts his glass.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And so few of us.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: (toasting) May there never be fewer. Swann takes a sip of the pungent cordial, pulls a face. T Doctor gestures toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: The Chinese were brought here to build the railroad. We were useful because we worked hard, and were fungible. Do you know what that means, Mr. Swann? That one of us was the same as any other. When there were obstacles in the course of the railroad, most often they would lower a basket with a Chinaman and several sticks of dynamite. If the dynamite went off prematurely, well, the fine for killing a Chinaman was fifty dollars. Swann realizes that The Doctor is leading up to something THE DOCTOR (cont'd) We settled in what is now downtown. But there was great racial feeling against us. Many were killed on the street, for the simple crime of being who we were. We built elaborate tunnels, under what is now downtown LA, to hide from our pursuers. The Doctor points out the window. THE DOCTOR (cont'd) This part of town, this theme park Chinatown, was built after World War Two by real estate speculators. White speculators. And yet we moved here, into this travesty, because there was no place else in town they would let us live in peace.  49. Swann sips his drink. THE DOCTOR (cont'd) In the 1950s, when the whites of Los Angeles began to realize how much they hated the blacks, and the Hispanics, they forgot to pay such close attention to those with yellow skin. And so the Japanese, so recently our enemies, were allowed to move into downtown. "Little Tokyo." Occupying the very land that had been ours. (with great and terrible derision: ) "Infiniti." "Lexus." "Miata." (beat ) Forgive me, Mr. Swann, if I snort Swann seems to sense, with relief, where all this is lead THE DOCTOR (cont'd) Normally, Mr. Swann, the code would insist I protect any soul brave enough to eliminate a policeman. But I cannot bring myself to care, one way or another, what happens to this Japanese gentleman, this Gondo Ken. who is in residence at the Hotel Mondrian, room 313.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I do not know how to thank you.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: It seems, Mr. Swann, that I may live forever. So there will be time and time for you to express your thanks. Provided, of course, that you are around to express them. Which you might be, if you avoid acts of stupidity.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Is that a threat?

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: To avenge the death of a policeman is an act of stupidity. (beat ) It is almost the definition of stupidity. Swann heads for the door, whose frame has been built some low.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: You would not happen to know who Gondo Ken has been doing business with? The Doctor stares at the apothecary jar. Its contents: a thin object, beyond recognition.  50.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Patience, Mr. Swann. Patience and irony. For a longer life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several police cars, an ambulance, sirens, blaring horns, commotion, in front of the hotel's (very hip) entrance. In the center of the chaos: the silk-robed body of Emoret Gondo Ken's paramour, splayed out at odd, broken-doll ang the middle of the boulevard. Police CRIMINALISTS are marking, with yellow paint, the p of her lifeless body. The Coroner's MEN lift her onto a stretcher, leaving a familiar outline, white paint on bla asphalt, reminiscent of nothing so much as the Keith Hari print which loomed above the bed, where she and Ken made

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: caught in traffic. As he turns the curve toward La Cieneg traffic narrows into one lane, and Swann is able to see w blocked-off area in front of the Mondrian.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: (to himself) I'm like Juve now. (beat ) Always one step behind. Swann pulls his car to the curb, strides toward the hotel He contemplates the painted white outline. Watches as Emoretta's body is lifted into the ambulance. And overhea Duty Officer speaking into his radio.

dialogues.speaker: DUTY OFFICER
dialogues.text: APB for Ken Gondo. George Orange Nostril Dog Orange. Japanese, five foot seven, slim, black hair. Must be considered armed and dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entrance to the best room in the house, now cordoned with yellow "crime scene" tape. Guarded by two buff COPS. Swann, now sporting a thick moustache and horn-rimmed gla walks directly up to them without breaking stride.  51.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: (with immense authority) Coming through. CoP Hold it. Crime scene. Swann gives his best "don't-you-know-who-I-am" stare.

dialogues.speaker: COP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Coroner's orders. In one seamless gesture, Swann coughs, raising his left h his mouth. As his right hand darts behind him to extract wallet of a cop striding down the corridor. Swann flips open the wallet, presenting the gold badge, a had been in his hand all along.

dialogues.speaker: COP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir. Didn't recognize you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: navigates his way unobtrusively between various detective forensics experts, busy dusting for prints, putting evide samples in zip-loc bags, etc. Swann heads straight for the closet and, covering with hi goes through the pockets of Ken's jackets and trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swann's haul. Some loose change. A set of keys. And an Olympus 35mm autofocus pocket camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photo shop in a pod mall on Sunset Boulevard. Swann is back and forth, the now-empty Olympus swinging from his l hand.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE PHOTOS
dialogues.text: as they emerge in a strip from the print machine: * Ken and Hideki in front of the Gamble House in Pasadena * Ken and Hideki at Clifton's Cafeteria. * Emoretta, in bed, wearing a diaphanous negligee.  52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in his Lincoln, paused at the light as he heads steeply u from Sunset. He shuffles through the deck of photographs. * More cheesecake shots of Emoretta. * Ken and Hideki in front of Mann's Chinese Theater * Hideki in front of the Watts Towers. * Hideki in front of the Watts Towers, another angle. * Hideki, his arm wrapped around one of the Towers.

dialogues.speaker: FULL ON THE LINCOLN
dialogues.text: As Swann executes a serious high-speed U-turn, across thr lanes of traffic, pointing his car back downhill. As he f the accelerator, he steers with one hand, using the other remove the false moustache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam Rodia's magnificent, homemade monument. Glittering sp fashioned of smashed crockery, pot shards, bottlecaps, sm mirrors, all embedded in cement around an armature of rus structural steel. Swann, some distance away, by the abandoned railroad trac keeping a low profile. Using an old, comfortable pair of binoculars, he scans the towers patiently, as if he's bee waiting a long time, and is prepared to wait a lot longer A solitary guard locks the gate, locks the door to the sh Towers Museum, gets into an old, battered Camaro. Now it's just past sundown. Abruptly a black Honda Prelude SI with tinted windows, bl bumpers, black wheel skirts, slides to a halt in front of entrance. Gondo Ken, in a black karate outfit, gets out of the Hond scales the fence with a practiced ease, disappears over t Within moments, Ken is scaling Tower 2. Swann gets out of his Lincoln, closes the door quietly. Swann looks at the fence, deciding whether to duplicate K agile leap. Thinking the better of it, he extracts a thin of metal from his breast pocket, and goes to work on the  53. padlock. As he works the lock he glances up, from moment moment, at the Tower. SWANN'S POV: what seems to be Ken, still atop the Tower. The lock spans open. Swann carefully opens the gate-- Onl find himself staring at a barechested Gondo Ken. Staring, fact, down the barrel of the matte black Heckler & Koch. Looking up, to the top of the tower, he realizes that wha been looking at is Ken's karate shirt, flapping in the wi Ken throws Swann a pair of handcuffs.

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: A taste, if you will, of your own medicine, yes? Fasten yourself to the tower please. Carefully, Ken takes two steps forward, cuffs Swann's oth wrist to the iron armature.

dialogues.speaker: KEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My apologies. I killed that smarmy Frenchman when the person I should have killed is you. I should have done it years ago. In fact, if my father had killed your parents before you were born, it would have spared the world a great many tears.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I think you are making a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: Your men kill my father. They leave me for dead. They throw my lover out the window. There's a warrant out for my arrest and my best Matsuda sport jacket is in a hotel room I can't go back to. Some kind of mistake? I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I wish I had known. I would have brought your jacket.

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: In the old days, when a man behaved as you had, we would show him photographs of an arousing nature. And then, when his penis was erect, jam a thin glass rod down the slit. A couple of blows with a hammer was sufficient to shatter that glass rod into hundreds of small, painful fragments. Of which the man would be aware, for the rest of his life, every time he'd urinate. Unless, of course he chose to end the agony by cutting off his own cock.  54. Swann, listening.

dialogues.speaker: KEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are not the old days. I will content myself, quite simply, with your death. And with the pleasure that you will never get your hands on the chip, Mr. Fantémas. With his left hand, Ken holds up a small object, no large a tie pin.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: My name is Charles Swann. The person you call Fant6mas retired, twenty-five years ago. I am sorry about your father, whom I never had the pleasure of meeting, and about your woman friend. But I had nothing to do with their deaths, nothing at all. With great contempt, Ken flings, at his feet, the bloodst FANTOMAS business card with the "0" shot through.

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: I had thought you were evil. Now I see what you really are. Which is: a coward. Squeezing the grips, he cocks the automatic, pumping a ro into the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: KEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In the name of my father. Ken takes steady aim. Swann gazes implacably into the fac his assassin. We hear someone whistling: the syncopated triplets of the theme, Bach's Sixth Cello Suite. A shot rings out. A ricochet's nasty whine, as a section of the Tower's fragi mosaic explodes into dust Abruptly Ken falls to the ground, dead-- As Swann stares amazement . Swann looks up to see Lem Hardt, smoke wafting upward fro muzzle of a CZ-75. Lem walks over to the felled body of G Ken, and prizes from the lifeless left hand the small obj which cost the lives of Gondo Hideki, Juve, Emoretta, now Taking his time, Lem turns his gun toward Swann. For the time in less than a minute, Swann faces the end of the li

dialogues.speaker: LEM
dialogues.text: Look at it this way. If I hadn't shown up you'd already be dead.  55. Lem takes aim. But before he can fire, a figure, backlit headlights of a white Rolls Royce, calls out to him.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: Hold. Hollywood walks over to the foot of the tower.

dialogues.speaker: A BEARDED FIGURE
dialogues.text: his features half-seen in the harsh backlighting. Swann, squinting, finds the face tantalizingly familiar.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not yet. Hollywood chokes: a paroxysm of coughing. Covers his hand his mouth. Swann watches them walk away. Something in Hollywood's vo and gesture--is frighteningly familiar.

dialogues.speaker: LEM
dialogues.text: We take it down to the lab, have the guys dissect it, draw diagrams, put it into production--

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: With our own, um, "improvements," of course.

dialogues.speaker: LEM
dialogues.text: Of course. They get into the white Rolls.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: watches as it turns away, north, leaving the ghetto. And he gazes at his own manacled hands.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: (to himself) I should be dead. Why am I not dead? He gazes at the damage to the tower, where a section of t crockery mosaic has been blown away by Lem's hollow-point bullet.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Vandals.  56. And then Swann, who's been holding his thin lockpick in h mouth, goes to work on the handcuffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pouring water through a coffee filter full of freshly gro beans. We hear the sound of water running somewhere else house. Swann continues pouring with a gentle circular mot quite rapt. Nora enters, hair wet. Swann takes a second bowl from the shelf, heats up some milk.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: These were your mother's bowls. She and her father used to drink out of them, every morning, on the Rue Mouffetard. Nora begins to read the newspaper. SWANN (cont'd) It is a street with cobblestones, a market street, very old, in the fifth arrondissement You should go there some day, take a look.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: It's Monday. You always said that the flannel cakes at Musso's were at their best on Mondays.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I am little tired today. I think I will stay in and read. Swann pours the milk and coffee, twin-handed. And reaches the paper. SWANN (cont'd) The young man Eddie. More spunk than Mr. Killer Bee, but still, too young I think. Throw him back. Here. Your mother's bowl.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I am twenty-four years old. I make my own living. I have a postdoctoral fellowship--

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: --and you do not want me running your social life. She looks at him.  57. SWANN (cont'd) What you do not understand-- How fragile life is. How vulnerable. Your mother, may she rest in peace-- Nora flings her coffee bowl across the room.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: You sit in that goddam chair and all I hear about -- (beat ) Mother. Mother. She walks quickly about the room. NORA (cont'd) This is America! You can breathe! You can-- Walk outside! (beat ) It's not Sarajevo! It's not-- (spat out:) Dien Bien Phu! Calmly, deliberately, without any fuss at all, Swann pick the shards of the broken bowl, places them on a sheet of newspaper, trying to make them fit. He's good with his ha But the fragments are just too small.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: If something were to happen to you. I would never rest.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: A father's duty is to protect his family. Someday, you will understand this.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Someday, when I have children of my own? Swann's eye is caught by something in the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: THE NEWSPAPER, BUSINESS SECTION
dialogues.text: A story about industrialist Victor Hollywood, conglomerat extraordinaire. Hollywood, the article says, has just ten an offer for another company, this one called Infotech, a microchip manufacturing plant in Carson. The photo featur Hollywood smiling broadly, waving his raised right hand a "v" of victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smiling, bearded face. You can almost see it silhouet the white Rolls headlights, uttering offhandedly the word spared--for that moment--Swann's life. NORA (cont'd) And now am I supposed have those children, if you won't let me leave the house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Victor Hollywood. His gesture: V for victory. V for Vi

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to get to work.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I can fix breakfast for myself, thank you. We watch Swann's face as he recalls where he last saw tha particular gesture. A few days back, in a downtown alleyw the final silent words of Theophile Juve. On the television monitor, the anchorwoman is introducing story. Last night's murder, it seems. With live coverage the Watts Towers. SWANN (cont'd) Just worry about yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again among his Fantémas objects. The opera cape. Th cane. The classic paraphernalia. We watch him finger the objects, one by one, as if each o its own special poignance. And then, like a Samurai preparing for battle, Swann take the black moire silk mask. He wraps it around his face, f first time in 25 years. It fits, exactly: the mask's slit coinciding perfectly with his steely eyes, slightly moist gazing into the middle distance. On a high shelf: the fragments of Céline's broken bowl, n quite fitted together-- Something from another time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pleasure dome, main entrance. The formal gate, of wro iron, has, dead-center, Hollywood's monogram: a Bauhaus-s  59.

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: Behind a topiary hedge is a very serious electrified fenc topped with concertina wire, surveilled by video cameras. see Swann's Lincoln convertible, top down, empty, largely concealed by the dense cliffside shrubbery. A little furt along: a small hole dug beneath the chain-link. And just beyond, a bowing of the electrified wire, just wide enoug for person to squeeze through. On the mansion, one wall of which is being scaled by a ju visible figure. All in black, Fantémas mask wrapped tight around his face, Swann moves from handhold to handhold, s upward. His body is sixty-odd years old; but as if the ri the mask granted him a special grace he moves without hesitation. We begin to hear the sound of VOICES from inside the mans

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room from which Hollywood conducts his business. One wall is filled, floor to ceiling, with television monitor the middle of the room is a large circular desk of ebony rosewood, equipped with built-in phones and terminals. We to get a sense of the reach of Hollywood's empire. Around the circumference: three of Hollywood's most trust associates, all eyes directed inward, to the circle's dea center, in which is a large red leather chair. The dealer spot. At the moment occupied by Victor Hollywood, in a ny jogging jacket, terrycloth sweatbands around his wrists, any Beverly Hills mogul working from home. On his right hand, in the power spot and not by accident, HARDT. To his left is a smarmy yes-man, ELLIOT WEST. Acro the table: WARREN SIROTA, chief wonk, technical division.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: It would be possible, in this situation, to get something for nothing. To use the weakness of others to our own clever advantage. That would be the way of the fox. West grins, perhaps a bit too smugly, thinking he's won. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) The times, however-- Lem, triumphant.  60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hanging from a rope as he works his way up to a partly op third-story window. There is a light mist of sweat on his as he starts to show exertion for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD, (VO)
dialogues.text: --call for the lion.

dialogues.speaker: SIROTA
dialogues.text: What we have in the vault upstairs is four generations beyond current Intel product Let's call it an 80986: a Novium.

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: Forgive me-- but we can't be the only people who'll be manufacturing this thing.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: Just the first. And the only ones to implant, within the CPU itself, some rather special features. One of the video monitors along the far wall is now displ shot of the exterior of the mansion. There is a slight disturbance in the video picture, barely discernible, jus the threshold of what we can perceive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black-clad figure against the black night, lifting hims feet-first, through an upper-story window.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: We can hide a gigabyte of ROM--our ROM-- invisibly, within. He begins to pace HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) It tells the CPU to use the sound card as a microphone. To monitors the static deflection caused by light falling on the CRT. In short this chip transmits. An eye and ear in every office-- Some bedrooms too, I would imagine. Obligatory laughter.  61. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) We have a pilot program in place. We've put the ROM in some five thousand television sets, mostly hotels. Mr. Sirota, if you will-- Could you access number One one three one? The number clearly was not picked at random. Because on t video monitors, we can see the picture (blurry) and hear sounds (quite clear) of a fat, middle-aged man, tied to a being whipped by a young woman in a black lace bustier.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Each installation currently costs us eighteen thousand dollars. With the chip, twenty-three cents apiece. "At certain points, a change in quantity becomes a change in quality." Unquote Karl Marx. Or was it Scary Spice? I get them confused. Obligatory laughter, led by West

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhat smaller than Dodger Stadium. Clean white tile, f to ceiling, exercise machines, sauna, steam, a sunken bat you could do laps in. Swann treads the tiles with an extraordinarily light step, making no noise whatsoever Along the ceiling, at various points, are sound sensors, the alarm system-- Which, one by one, Swann plugs with si putty. On the wall is a framed Salvador Dali oil painting: melti watches in a surreal landscape, encased in Plexiglas agai water damage. Swann notices a video camera in the corner trained direct the painting. And turns on the shower, hot, full blast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The video display. One of the screens shows the Dali, whi BLURS TO GREY as the condensation from the shower mists u lens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: notices a thin beam of laser-light, at eye level, crossin room inches in front of the Dali. Swann thinks for just a moment, then picks up a hand-mirror from the sink, and a compact disc player from the bathtub's edge.  62. Swann's elegant, capable fingers locate the laser arm, be upward. He places the CD player in front of the portrait positioning it with supreme care. With one confident flou Swann pulls the hand-mirror down into the alarm-beam at a angle. The electric eye at the end of the tiled wall is now rece not the alarm-beam, but the laser-light from the CD, boun of the mirror. The Dali now unprotected, Swann slides it upwards, to rev dial of a sunken wall safe.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: There's another feature within the chip which bears some mention. It's the one which flashes subliminal messages to anyone watching television, or working at a personal computer. You know: EAT AT JOE'S. Or maybe, VOTE FOR VICTOR.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Contraindications? Lem shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Downside?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: Well, this wouldn't exactly be the best time for the newspapers to be looking into my past.

dialogues.text: has attached an electromagnet to the outside of the safe Now he reaches into his black coat for a vial of iron fil which he throws at the safe. The filings stick. Now, as Swann's practiced hands work the combination lock, the fi re-align in complex moire patterns. Swann is all concentr gazing intently at the patterns as they tell him which wa twist the dial.

dialogues.text: just his eyes, through the Fantémas mask.  63.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: The only people who might talk about that, ah, part of my history are in this room. With two exceptions. The one, as you know, is the Chancellor, of, what's that country? The laughter comes more easily now. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) The other is an old, old friend. And ina manner of speaking-- On the video monitors: as the bathroom condensation evapo from the camera lens, we see, quite unmistakably, the fig Charles Swann, black clothes and black mask, bent before wall safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alarm lights begin to flash. At the big desk PROCTOR GEORGE, Hollywood's white-haired head of security, whispe orders into his phone handset. George's security team--three GOONS in 3-piece pinstripes gold "VH" medallions pinned to their pockets--pick up the and begin to fan out. (It's what the Secret Service would like, if Bijan were elected President.)

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: --I've already sent for him. The progress of the security team, as followed on four di monitors. Hollywood is standing now, speaking into a hand-held mike front of the wall of video monitors, like a rockstar, ora karaoke singer.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into the microphone) Silence, gentlemen. Speed, order, silence. No one shoots, no one gets hurt.  64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Uzi, separated from Swann's head by six inches and a w door. Two more guns, cocked with a thin, metallic "click, trained on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: working the safe. We watch his fingers, and the almost ab display of iron filings, shifting this way and that. Swann is a model of composure. He is staring at the safe, he could open it by the force of his gaze alone. Then, as if in response, the safe opens! Inside: A thick of yellowing envelopes (love letters?) bound in wine-red An exquisite diamond and platinum necklace. And a small b chip--the Novium--the size and shape of a tie tack. Swann grabs the necklace. And changes posture entirely, as if the air had been let him. One moment before, he was a man of pride and eleganc he seems old, and defeated. There is a tremble in his rea he takes the chip. With what's left of his energy, Swann reaches up, pulls t putty from one of the "hidden" microphones. Unties his si mask, uses it to wipe the condensation from the monitor c And looks directly into the lens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: all of them now carrying the same image. Swann, repeated repeated, 24 pairs of eyes staring balefully down.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch. We see him turn his back on the camera in a gesture of ut contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: walks away from the camera. And then, in one swift, elega sweep, grabs the electromagnet from the safe and clamps i the videocamera which has been monitoring him.  65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Complete pointillist static.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: (into the microphone) Hold him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: breaks the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Swann. They rush to the open window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swann, slowly lowering himself by rope down to the lawn. spotlight hits and holds. Above him, the three security guards, guns trained. Below Proctor George, his Uzi trained steadily on the descendin figure. Hollywood emerges from the mansion.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR GEORGE
dialogues.text: "No violator lives to talk." Your rule, Mr. Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: Don't be an ass. George looks at Hollywood. Lowers his gun, walks away. Si his men to do the same. Swann takes his time; then, with a flourish, drops the la or so feet to the ground, landing like a cat.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN AND HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: It's just the two of them now.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fant6mas.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Mabuse.  66.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: Friends call me Victor Swann says nothing. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) Climbing up the sides of buildings. At your age. (beat ) You could have gotten yourself -- Swann just stares. His face has never been more full of h than it is at this moment. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: The necklace is the one I gave to Céline on our anniversary. You have no right to it.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: "Right"?

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: She was wearing it the night she died. Hollywood says nothing. SWANN (cont'd) When the police pulled her car. From the bottom of the lake. It was never found.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: I guess I got there first.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: What could it possibly mean to you?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: The necklace for the chip. Swann holds the chip in his palm, contemplates, then hand over. Hollywood gives him the necklace.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I owe you nothing now. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: I miss her too. The remark is too much for Swann to bear. All control gon leaps on Hollywood, hands around the other's neck  67. We have never seen Swann with so little restraint. It is frightening.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: How did she die? Dammit! How did she die? Within moments, the GUARDS have separated them. Hollywood stands there, slightly bruised, breathing heavi suppressing his cough. Swann's hair disheveled, and his impeccable starched white shirtfront is missing a stud.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: You tell me. Swann is frozen. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) You wouldn't let her go. You wouldn't let her live. She was dying inside and you didn't even see. And when she made her choice--

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear this!

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: You never have. The two men stare at each other for the longest while. Pr George walks slowly up to Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR GEORGE
dialogues.text: My turn?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: No. Hollywood brushes the grass and dirt off his shoulder. Hi is thin, drawn. He's been triumphant in presenting the ne his associate, victorious against Swann-- But you wouldn' it from his face, which registers no joy. Just a dry cough. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) Leave him his dignity.

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOWING SWANN
dialogues.text: as, courtesy of Hollywood, he walks back to his car. He's limping slightly. And his shoulders have a stoop we've no before. As if, for the first time, he's been defeated.  68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guns the motor of the '61 Lincoln and zooms off, heading down the Pacific Coast Highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lincoln turns inland, up the winding roads, toward Mulholland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swann, taking from his watch pocket the microchip-- The r Novium, not the dress-shirt stud he handed to Hollywood. puts is in the drawer. And lets his fingers run, listless across the necklace... His revery is interrupted by the high whistle--from the k upstairs--of a teakettle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swann and Nora, having tea and pastry, eating off a break bed tray that Swann has carried into his daughter's room. dressed; she's still in bed, in a long white flannel nigh Outside the window the sky is blue, the clouds fluffy and the air transparent. One of those days, you understand wh someone might want to live in Los Angeles. She sips at her tea. Then:

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: How did you meet?

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: "How"?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Just-- Just, the "how."

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Ahh. Well. (beat ) There are many ways of telling the story--

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Tell this one.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: More tea?  Then:

SWANN (cont'd) It starts with a book. An extraordinary book. Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea. The first Hetzel edition. Leather, and gold leaf, and each signature sewn by hand. You have never seen such beautiful work. You look at the cover, and you know, that the world is inside, just waiting to be opened up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking this all in. SWANN (cont'd) I saw it at a bookstall, a bouquiniste, on the left bank of the Seine. I would visit-- Many times. It was priced fairly, for what it was, but well beyond the means of someone such as I. Nora takes a cube of sugar, lifts it with delicate silver drops it carefully into her tea. SWANN (cont'd) Then I could stand it no more. I went back one day, at closing time to-- (Choosing his word carefully: ) Obtain the book. And-- (beat ) It was gone. The book to the right, the book to the left, and in between-- Air He leans back, his eyes lost in revery. He puts gesture: SWANN (cont'd) All the bookseller could tell me, is that it had been purchased, a scant hour previous, by a beautiful, intelligent charming young woman. The most enchanting woman, he'd ever met in his life. (beat ) He knew not where she lived, or what she did-- Nor her last name. Just-- That she called herself Céline. his hand on that of his daughter. A small, fugitive but it's the first time we've seen them touch. SWANN (cont'd) Céline. Six letters. All I had to go on. (beat ) I wandered the city of Paris, my mind on fire. Céline. Céline. At dawn, scanning the lines (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. 70. SWANN(cont 'd) at the boulangeries. The museums, the parks by day. Twilight, haunting every bohemian café a woman who loved Jules Verne might go. (beat ) Nothing. Then:

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: You looked all your life. Circled the globe. And never found her. (beat ) "The end." Swann actually laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Of course I found-- Of course we found each other. (beat ) Quai Henri IV, on the Tle de la Cité. Where the Seine splits in two. You look up, and you see the Pont Neuf. You look out, and you see-- The world. I was there, beneath the bridge on my way from-- An appointment. It was July. The skies, as they will, opened up. From bright sun, to conflagration, in the blink of an eye. He looks out to the canyons, the city beyond. SWANN (cont'd) A young woman, about to get soaked. Me, with a green umbrella, large enough for two. Just that-- (beat ) Simple. As her father talks, Nora's eyes begin to gleam-- To glis Swann's gaze is elsewhere: SWANN (cont'd) We walked. I introduced myself. She responded in kind. And when she said, just like that, I still hear it, when she said-- (beat ) Moi, je m'appelle Céline. (beat ) Well, I knew it was her. He fusses with his cloth napkin. Wiping, with great delic every last crumb from his mouth. SWANN (cont'd) And, of course, it was.  71. He looks up. To discover that... ...in a restrained and utterly silent way... ...his daughter is crying. SWANN (cont'd) Nora. Nora. She says nothing. The tears fall, silently, down her face. SWANN (cont'd) More tea? A beat. Then: SWANN (cont'd) I can-- Show you the book?

dialogues.speaker: ON SWANN
dialogues.text: not realizing that of all the things he could have said.. ...this offers, by far, the least comfort.

dialogues.speaker: ON NORA
dialogues.text: staring, at her father; and then, past him-- --as, head down, he walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Catholic mission in the old style. From the adobe tower bell tolls sonorously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old-style Mission interior, dark light streaming in th stained-glass windows. At the altar, an aged priest, FATH BARRAGAN, is reading from a typed manuscript. In the audience--perhaps five people. Among them: Eddie, second-hand black-on-blue sharkskin suit, Kennedy-era.

dialogues.speaker: BARRAGAN
dialogues.text: --to the rank of Chief Inspector. Not an honorific given lightly. And what did Theophile Juve do with this lofty position? Did he accept the quotidian graft which, in (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARRAGAN (cont 'd) that day, was the daily bread of the inspector? Did he look the other way? He shakes his head balefully: no. BARRAGAN (cont'd) Instead, he selflessly devoted his life to the pursuit of those spidery criminals too dangerous, too evil for others to pursue. The insidious Fu Manchu. The heinous Mabuse. And perhaps blackest of all, Fantémas. Nora, dressed in black, enters the church tentatively. An seats herself in the back row. BARRAGAN (cont'd) Many times he came near to meting out the justice these archcriminals so richly deserved. In 1961, he did what no other policeman, before or since, has ever done: he apprehended Fantémas. That villain's subsequent escape--from the very neckrest of the guillotine--in no way casts shadow upon Theophile Juve's unique achievement. Barragan takes a hasty gulp from a glass of "water." Eddi looks back to see Nora. BARRAGAN (cont'd) After his retirement from the Sdreté Nationale, Theophile Juve made his home in Los Angeles, where his generosity and sunny disposition brightened the day of all those with whom he came in contact. Never one to dwell on the past, this man, this father, this citizen--

dialogues.text: As eight hired pallbearers carry the coffin containing th remains of Theophile Juve down to the cemetery. Behind th the mourners, all three of them: Eddie, Nora, and Father Barragan.

dialogues.text: The way I look at he-- He should get the kind of speech he would have wanted.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Are you--

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I'm fine. (beat ) You know how they say, he was like a father to me? Well, my father-- (beat ) He wasn't. She looks at him. Takes his hand. Presses it.

dialogues.text: By the side of the grave is Mr. Victor Hollywood, thin an He's surrounded by three bodyguards and a video crew. As funeral cortege approaches, Hollywood is making good eye with the local news reporter.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: When I came to this town, I did not know a soul in California. And thanks to the kindness of ordinary citizens, like Mister Juve, may he rest in peace, I was able to begin to do business. When there was no reason to give me the time of day, Mister Juve paid attention. Today, it would be just as easy to stay home, gaze at the Pacific. But he was there for me, and now it's my turn to come through for him... The pallbearers approach. As he catches sight of Hollywoo Swann's face, beneath the false beard, tightens with tens The Doctor whispers in Swann's ear.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We have our rules about funerals. Always have. You know that. Swann says nothing. THE DOCTOR (cont'd) Besides, it would be suicide.
