dialogues.text: I have this problem, doctor. I've been walking around for twenty years with a desperate need and I only just realized it this morning.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I believe I warned you, repeatedly, about stupidity. I was stupid once. It was in the International Settlement of Shanghai, when the Japanese invaded, and my stupidity caused me to be captured. He lights his pipe. THE DOCTOR (cont'd) They had way of dealing with enemies. It involved a man's private parts, and a thin glass rod-- Swann looks at him. THE DOCTOR (cont'd) You are familiar, then, with the choices presented to man upon whom this has been practiced. Swann nods.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have never been good about physical pain. Even with the opium, it was not something I could bear. A week later, in a basement in the French Concession, I surgically removed my own penis.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I am genuinely sorry.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I have not missed it. It is an amazing thing what one can accomplish, once one decides to leave one's pain behind. He taps the apothecary jar. The object within moves fractionally, floating within the formaldehyde. THE DOCTOR (cont'd) I keep this here, as a reminder of what has been taken from me. And what has not. It has become, for me, quite a source of inspiration.  96. Swann tries not to stare at the jar

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Still. Stupid or not. I need your help. And your protection. The Doctor relights his pipe.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fully dressed, on the bed of a tacky economy hotel room o ass end of Sunset Strip, near La Brea. There is a television set in the corner, its tube facing directly toward the bed.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It's not fair. You have your stuffed bear. I don't even have a guitar.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Are you in a band?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Was. (beat ) Went on tour once. (beat ) Third on the bill to a power trio. Old guys in tights and eyeliner.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: What made you stop?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I didn't want to move up.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: What'd you do then?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Computer stuff. Hacking.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Any good at it?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Enough.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Why'd you stop?  97. Eddie says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then? Eddie gets up from the bed, and starts lining the floor w sheets of crumpled newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Tell me about your-- Spiders.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Signals. Webs. Hieroglyphics, really. Where the food is. Where danger lurks. Near, far. Which direction. Eddie leans back. They are almost touching.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Anyway. Nora says nothing. EDDIE (cont'd) Anyway what are you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: I'm thinking that you're just as pigheaded as my father. Eddie leans over. NORA (cont'd) But - - (beat ) --maybe-- They kiss. NORA (cont'd) Cuter. Slowly, they begin to make love. Within moments: Nora's clothes are off and Eddie's clothes are off and th slide against each other in a tangle of limbs, bodies, intuitions. Discovering each other-- Discovering parts of themselves long kept secret. In their heat, Eddie and Nora are so fully absorbed that not hear--as we do--the opening of the door... ...or the crunching of the newspaper.  98.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE TURNS HIS HEAD
dialogues.text: to see Elliot West and three of Hollywood's security GOON They're pointing their silenced Czech automatics.

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: "Mister and Mrs. Smith." Original. Nora pulls a sheet over her body. Eddie moves to protect WEST (cont'd) I'd bet you could not produce a marriage license. The goons guffaw.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You touch her and you're dead. More laughter. EDDIE (cont'd) Leave her alone and I'll tell you where you can find the chip.

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: I don't do business with assholes. (to Nora) Get dressed, lady. You're coming home with us.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Could you-- turn your backs?

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: Not a chance. Eddie CHARGES him. One goon gives him a clout with the bu of the pistol. Like a maddened bull, Eddie rises, charges first, at West. Two of the goons knock him back to the gr kicking him viciously, in the kidneys, and in the head. Nora looks on in horror.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: You don't have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: We don't have to. We want to. (beat ) Put your clothes on. Beneath the sheet, Nora wriggles into her clothes. Eddie, cold, lies on the floor, curled up into a ball. His blood  99. stains the carpet. One of the goons gives him another kic good measure... ...but Eddie does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nondescript downtown Chinese restaurant: Formica tables fluorescent lights. A few diners, all Chinese, are eating and sipping soup when: BANG! through the doors come three West, Hollywood, three more goons. All carrying Uzis. The goons charge through the restaurant, through the kitc down a flight of stairs, into the men's room. The goons s against one of the stalls, which opens, revealing another staircase. We FOLLOW them down three flights, along a dark, narrow corridor. Down a steep spiral staircase. Down into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The subterranean city built by Chinese immigrants at the the century. Complete with stores, restaurants, housing. along the sides of four-foot wide tunnels. With an abrupt snap, one of the goons finds himself hangi upside down from a hemp ankle noose. They leave him there There is a gunshot, and another goon drops to the ground. third goon fires at a dimly seen moving figure, who drops his niche carved into the tunnelside. It marks the beginn a full-scale gun battle between Hollywood's security goon the young Chinese who work for The Doctor. When the smoke clears, The Doctor's troops have been out- Hollywood, West, and the two remaining security goons sta outside the large wooden door to the room where Swan is h up.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: It's over, Charley. Come on out. No reply. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) I've got something I want to show you. Still no reply. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) A television show. Starring your daughter.  100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens slowly. There's Charles Swann, still shave headed, in a rumpled white-tie formal suit, in a room sca larger than a prison cell. There is a canvas cot, a small table, one wooden chair, a bare light bulb. That's it. Hollywood enters. West and the goons remain outside. Hollywood places on the table a battery-powered 8mm VCR, to a color Watchman. He switches on the tape.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: (on the videotape) I don't want you to worry about me. I'm all right --

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: That's enough. Hollywood turns it off.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: Do I get the chip? Swann reaches into the watch pocket of his white formal v pulls out the chip. As he hands it over

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: You have gotten what you came for. Why don't you kill me?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: You're better than me, Charles. Always were. And I guess there's always been a hope-- The Spiders. You, me, The Doctor. It's not too late.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Fuck yourself.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: What happened, Charles? You used to be a pretty evil dude.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Still am.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: Il faut plonger le monde dans un abime... "We must plunge the world into an abyss of terror." Your words. Remember, Charles?  101. Hollywood laughs. The laughter becomes a spasm of coughs. sense that Hollywood is quite ill. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) When times changed. I changed with them. You're still the anarchist, running across the rooftops. Swann says nothing. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) You're sixty years old. This town has no rooftops.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Viktor. Look at yourself. You're not evil. You're just-- Corrupt.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: Why don't we say, "well-networked."

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: You used to know better, Viktor

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: Why are you so afraid of-- The big time?

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: That's not crime. That's organized crime. (with great disgust: ) Work. Business. Civilization. (beat ) You know what civilization is? (beat ) War, without all the noise. Hollywood just tosses the chip in his palm. Up, and down.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: I'll have Sirota check it out. If it's real, nothing will happen to your daughter

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I cannot believe that you would bring my daughter into this. Céline's daughter

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: It's the real world, Charles. You can't protect people from the real world. Hollywood stands up.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: I worked for more than twenty years to keep her away from this. Now you have shown her (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWANN(cont 'd) things she should never have seen. For that alone, you are dead. Hollywood opens the door. He holds up the chip; and his g smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sweeping lazily around the curves of Sunset, out toward t beach. It's a bright, sunny morning; and there's no other traffic. Swann, still dressed in his rumpled cutaway, is singing a with a Bob Dylan song on the oldies station.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (on the radio) ".-When you ain't got nothin', you got nothin' to lose/ You're invisible now, you got no secrets/ To conceal. How does it feel?" In the back seat of the open-topped convertible are seven sticks of dynamite, taped up, fully wired. Swann is smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swann takes the turnoff for Hollywood's estate. With one hand, he pulls the black silk moire mask over hi aligning the slits with his eyes. He FLOORS the accelerator. By the time he reaches the gat the estate, he's doing ninety. He plows right into the gate, which smashes open. Immedia the sirens start to wail. Swann, heading straight for the house, picking up speed, pokes away the shards of shatter windshield with his right hand. From one of the onion towers, a security goon, fully Bija out, OPENS FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: THE WHITE ROLLS
dialogues.text: with Hollywood at the wheel, pulls out of the garage. As black Lincoln heads for the house, the white Rolls angles aiming to intercept. Swann realizes who's driving the Rolls, and veers away fr house, directly towards his nemesis. The black and white approach each other at frightening speed.  103. Hollywood executes a swift, full-power U-turn, forcing Sw circle, coming once more within range of the tower gunman when he seems directly in the line of fire, Swann swerves the massive sculpture; and we hear the bullets ricochetin the thick, sinuous steel. But as Swann emerges from behind the Serra, slowing for t turn, his side is presented directly to the Rolls. Hollyw pulls out a pistol and takes careful aim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from Hollywood; another from the onion tower We see Swann's head SNAP BACK. His hands fall from the st wheel. The Lincoln, uncontrolled, accelerates mid-turn, heading straight for the Serra. Collides. There is a great explosion. The sky is bright white, then orange, then full of dark, acrid smoke. Pieces of the automobile drift lazily downward, as if in SLOW MOTION... ...forming a new sculpture--Serra meets John Chamberlain. »..on the manicured lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The simple Greek Revival building which houses the cremat

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (VO)
dialogues.text: Something he read to me. Once. A long time ago. The end of a story. Edgar Allen Poe. Parked outside, in the lot: Eddie's muscle car NORA (cont'd) (VO) (cont'd) I was in the crook of his arm, it was bedtime. Usually I fell asleep there, in the crook of his arm, before the story's end; but this night I stayed awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie takes a piece of cloth, and places it near the head plain pine box. Just before he closes the lid, we catch a glimpse: torn, frayed, black moire silk... ...the mask of FANTOMAS.  104. NORA (cont'd) (VO) It was about a man who'd done something bad, something very bad. Now he was in jail, awaiting execution. The box, on a conveyor belt, heads toward the oven, where dozen butane flames are waiting to consume it. NORA (cont'd) (VO) (cont'd) I still remember what he said, in my father's voice: (beat ) "Today I am in chains-- But here." Eddie holds Nora very close. Eddie, Nora, Nora's stuffed silhouetted against the intense white light of the crematorium...

dialogues.speaker: NORA, (VO)
dialogues.text: "Tomorrow I shall be free-- ...as the plain white pine box disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The harsh late-afternoon sun. A thin tendril of smoke, wa straight up, in the still, windless air. NORA (cont'd) (VO) "But-- Where?" Eddie, Nora, holding each other, looking out: The freeway, it's traffic, the valley, the mountains... ...the darkening world beyond.

dialogues.speaker: INT. EDDIE'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Sunday morning sunlight streaming in through the windows. The place looks neater, and cleaner, than we've seen it. surfboards, the computers, all in the back now. In the fr an easel, a stretched canvas. Nora is curled up in a larg chair while Eddie primes the canvas, singing softly to hi

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: ...The eensy weensy spider crawls up the water spout... Now Eddie notices something out of the corner of his eye. envelope: white, protruding, almost beckoning, just benea door.  105. A white envelope with a red wax seal.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: What is it? Eddie takes a few light steps, carefully hiding the envel from view with his foot.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's battered muscle car parked outside of a boarded-u moviehouse, downtown LA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A once-magnificent moviehouse, now shut down. The ornate ceilings and proscenium surround an auditorium of worn, f velvet seats. We FOLLOW Eddy across the empty stage, in front of the sc At once he is silhouetted by a shaft of light from the projectionist's booth.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Up here! Eddie squints into the light. There is a metal cable dang from the booth. He grabs the cable and starts upward. The cable is slippe he's not used to this kind of activity. For every three f he slips back two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in black, reading an old almanac. It's a bare room--one c one chair--of the type Swann seems to favor. The room is with 35mm film reels and spare projector parts. Eddie--sweating, breathless--clambers through the rectang opening.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: (without looking up) We have work to do.  106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fireplace. An oversized bureaucrat's desk from the Brit Raj. A couple of comfy chairs, done up in well-worn red leather. Nothing high-tech at all, in fact, nothing twent century, except for a telephone, and a modest television built into the rolltop taboret. Hollywood, behind the desk, emaciated, just flesh and bon Idly flicking the television remote. Image after image of bedrooms, living rooms. Mostly blurr Mostly of families, zombied out, staring directly at the

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: (on the screen) Honey, have you seen the orange juice? Hollywood changes the channel. Two men in a business discussion. Click. A couple fucking. Click. He flicks aga and again, looking for something to hold his interest There is no intimacy which Hollywood cannot access. More anything, he seems painfully bored. Hollywood clears his throat, punching up another bedroom. tried, quite hard, to avoid another coughing fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a floor plan of Hollywood's mansion projected on screen. Swann gestures with his pointer, narrates.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: This is office. Locked door, locked windows. According to The Doctor, nobody enters, nobody leaves. Once a day, West brings the mail on a tray. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: So how to we get in?

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: We don't.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Good. Let's go home.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you... He leans back. As if about to settle in, for a bedtime st  107. SWANN (cont'd) ..,about Lord Halifax?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nora is carrying a large cage, covered with a black dropc and a metal thermos. She passes the SECURITY GUARD, a you black woman, with whom she is apparently on friendly term

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Dr. Swann.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Evening.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: I've got another six hours. (pointing to the thermos) Mind if I borrow some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: Actually it's not coffee. Actually it's a horrible, disgusting black widow spider, its sac full of deadly venom.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Well then... (beat ) ...mever mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swann and Eddie, in the rear of the orchestra section.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: One more time.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: He gets the note. Opens it. Smells his hands. Smells amaryllis. Screams. (beat ) You, you're up here, you lower the spider. He runs down the hall, around the corner, the nearest place he can wash the scent off his hands. The bathroom... (beat ) ...where, of course, I'll be waiting.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What if he doesn't know the saga of Lord Halifax?  108.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: He knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark, looming castle behind the iron gate. Again, the

dialogues.speaker: H
dialogues.text: logo, dead-center. But now the gate has been repaired, augmented with welded steel cross-bracings; and a machine nest, behind an embankment of sandbags, lies just beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Security goons patrol the corridors. There are far more o than we've seen before. A trio of them stand at dress att outside the door to Hollywood's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollywood, propped up in his chair, behind the colonial d Still flicking the television remote, but too listless, n pay attention. There is a knock on the door. Elliot West arrives with a sterling tray of mail, places it on the de

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: Everything okay, sir? Hollywood makes no reply. Doesn't even notice when West l Numbed by the television but unable to stop watching, Hol distractedly opens envelope after envelope, considers the contents, tosses. Then stops. An envelope with a blood-red seal. An intaglio'd F. Slowly, Hollywood tears the flap. The card is written in impeccable Copperplate: stamped deeply into the wax. For Céline, for Juve, for everyone on television.  109. Hollywood is toying with the card when his nose starts to twitch. Abruptly, he leaps up.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: Amaryllis! Then sits down again. A smiles flickers across his face, For the first time in a long while, Hollywood seems--At p Glancing toward the fireplace, with Zen-like calm, Hollyw awaits the arrival of a black widow spider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FIGURE--black jeans, black shirt, black hood--perched a of Hollywood's minarets. Holding a large black metal box. now: dumping its contents down the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spiders, tumbling down the chimney, out the fireplace. No elegant spider on a silken cord, but hundreds of spiders thousands of SPIDERS, crawling across the floor, up the wainscoting, all deadly. And like all black widows, with congenital reflex that responds to the odor of amaryllis. Hollywood starts to cough. There is a spider crawling up his tweedy leg. He tries to motionless, but at the last moment gets the willies, and it. Another spider attaches itself to his jacket. We watch Hollywood trying, with all his might, to stay pu the chair. Then, screaming like a terrified child, he can it no more, and runs full-tilt for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollywood bursts through the door, scattering West and se goons. As he runs down the hall, they try to follow.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: Get back! Get back! My office! Spiders! Kill them! Kill them all! He turns a corner, runs down another corridor, past sever guards, through his bedroom, into his bathroom. Inspects himself for bugs. Locks the door frantically, all three l Turns on the shower, hot.  110. Hollywood, scrubbing himself down with brown soap. Pausin sniff his hands, then scrubbing some more. After a while, panic seems to leave his body. He wraps himself in a towel. As the condensation clears f the glass shower door, there seems to be something moving against white. Then, at once, the door is flung open. And dripping, towel-wrapped Hollywood finds himself face to f with Fantomas. We have never seen Swann in anything but black. Now, for first time, he is white, head to toe. White trousers, whi starched shirt, white tie, white formal vest, white tailc

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: You thought I was dead. well. (beat ) These things happen. Swann produces a flat white silk disk, snaps it against h forearm. It pops open: into a tophat.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am the polar bear at your funeral. Swann dons the tophat and, in the same motion, produces a from nowhere a white pearl-handled straight razor. It is Swann's moment of triumph: the plan, the surprise, punch lines, the tophat and the razor, perfect details perfectly chosen, perfectly played. One thing wrong: Hollywood. Whose reaction is not at all it should be.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: (calmly) Sit down. Swann looks straight at him and does not move. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) You are alive for only one reason: because time and time again, I did not kill you. In your home. At the watts Towers. In that little room in old Chinatown. In your clever little renovation of the Million Dollar Theater. Sit down, Charles. Swann sits. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) When the child was a child-- He has many choices. What he's going to be when he grows up. A fireman, a policeman, a cowboy. You (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLLYWOOD(cont 'd) get old, the world shuts down on you. All of a sudden your life is what it is. You have very few choices at all... Until, finally-- Just one. The manner and method of your own death. Swann, beginning to see the light. HOLLYWOOD (cont'd) I did not kill you because I wanted something. A proper death. Not this-- this cancer (he thumps his chest) Not "died in his sleep." Not "following surgery at Cedars of Lebanon." Something elegant, something fitting, something with a bit of marvel. Hollywood, in complete control, exhibits an energy we've seen from him in quite some while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliot West, perched precariously on the windowsill, thre stories up. He takes a large step to the next sill, the o beneath the bathroom window. Looks inside. Sees Swann and Hollywood talking, Swann with a blade in h hand. West extracts his CZ-70. Draws a bead on Swann. Hollywood is in the line of fire. But as Swann stands up, is nothing between Swann and the tip of West's automatic. Hollywood moves again, blocking the shot.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: The kind of death only Fantémas could provide. My only problem: Fantomas was asleep. Had been for twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: Dear sweet Lord..

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: So I had to wake him up. Put Juve on his tail. I-- I forged some letters, tied 'em with red ribbon. Told Lem Hardt a bunch of stuff I knew you'd force him to spill. And still it did not work. So I borrowed Nora.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: All-- To bring me to this room.  112. Hollywood nods: swiftly, solemnly. SWANN (cont'd) Me, with a leash around my neck. And I never saw it. We can hear the alarm sirens.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: I should tell you while I still can. Céline meant something to me. I meant very little to her. I think she wanted your attention. That's all I was, a way to catch your eye. I'm sorry it didn't work. For all of us. The two men regard each other for the longest time.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm ready now. (beat ) So are you. The guards, now, are banging at the door. But the room, o course, is locked from the inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollywood still blocking the target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swann begins to realize just how deeply Hollywood has wis this particular death. In a strange way, it's very moving

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: You leave me no choice.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: I mean not to.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: My brother.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLYWOOD
dialogues.text: My killer. With absolute calm, Swann runs the straight razor across Hollywood's pale white neck. A perfect arc, from which bl begins to bloom. In small rosettes at first. Then a thin sheet, like burgundy swirled in a crystal goblet... ...then torrents.  113. Hollywood clutches his neck, falls to the floor, his bloo charting its course, across the white tiled floor, to the drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Hollywood falls to the floor, West has a clear shot. H draws his bead. Begins to squeeze the trigger. Suddenly Eddie--clad in black, from head to toe--is swing from a rope, Douglas Fairbanks-style, sweeping from the t the onion tower, across the side of the mansion.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: J'arrive. He lands on the bathroom window ledge, knocking West's ar aside. The two grapple for the gun. As Eddie, for the moment, gains control of the gun:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (softly) I don't have to. I want to. Just below, another black-clad FIGURE climbs, spider-styl the craggy wall from the window below. Zigging, and zaggi uncanny emulation of the figure-eight web, the signal web Now the second black-clad figure REACHES UP... ...and PULLS West by the ankle. The gun falls, in a long arc, to the manicured lawn below

dialogues.speaker: WEST
dialogues.text: You son-of-a-bitch. He flails out-- --and FALLS-- --in a long arc, following his gun... ...all the way down.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MANSION
dialogues.text: strides toward the window, opens it, lifts himself out.  114. Eddie and Swann embrace, and Eddie swings them, by rope, the top of the onion tower. Three stories below, the life body of Elliot west. What Swann doesn't see: the other black-clad FIGURE, just the window ledge. The figure--as we've by now figured out NORA SWANN.

dialogues.speaker: SWANN
dialogues.text: (to Eddie) Get out of here. Now. (beat ) Somebody is going to have to pay for this. One will do as well as two.

dialogues.speaker: ON NORA
dialogues.text: listening to her father.

dialogues.speaker: ON SWANN
